abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. There are increases in graduate students
            trained at high levels of quality, enhanced capacity for
            such training in the future, and impressive research results
            emanating from the project. Laboratory management has
            improved and more effective technology transfer strategies
            are beginning. Overall, the project significantly
            contributed to Chinese research and advanced education
            capacities and to the modernization of thinking about
            research, education, and laboratory equipment. Key lessons
            learned from this project include: It is possible to
            accelerate China's scientific and technological
            development with appropriate resources and careful planning,
            and by training more graduate students at international
            levels of proficiency. It is difficult to transfer
            managerial experience acquired in other countries to China.
            Scarcity of equipment made the community maximize the amount
            of new equipment purchased, at the expense of acquiring
            adequate supplies of spare parts and consumables for the
            proper operation of that equipment. The sharing of major
            facilities at research and teaching institutions is hampered
            by the compartmentalized organizational structure within the
            science and technology community. Disseminating managerial
            know-how within and among laboratories is slow; more
            efficient means should have been adopted from the beginning.
            The Programme Advisory Group should have adopted a role akin
            to that of a managerial Principal Investigator.

18155201.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific
18155201.theme: Education for the knowledge economy,Technology diffusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The credit will support the
            government's decision issued in 1985, to reform the
            management of science and technology programs. The project
            will: (a) increase the output of scientific researchers
            trained to international standards through master, doctoral
            and post-doctoral programs; (b) enhance the quality and
            productivity of research in strategic areas relevant to
            long-term economic and social development; (c) strengthen
            the management of scientific research at both the national
            and laboratory level; (d) provide a modern scientific
            infrastructure for Chinese scientists trained at home and
            abroad; and (e) encourage scientific cooperation across
            institutional and national boundaries. The projectsists of:
            (a) support for research and graduate student training in
            133 State Key Laboratories (SKL) and Special Laboratories
            (SL) affiliated with universities and with the Chinese
            Academy of Sciences (CAS); (b) a pilot program to assist
            seven of the project laboratories to improve management
            efficiency and the quality of research and training of
            graduate students in science; (c) development of a
            demonstration computer network that will link Qinghua and
            Beijing Universities and the Computer Center of CAS, and
            establish an enhanced computing facility at the CAS center;
            and (d) a program advisory group (PAG) of Chinese and
            foreign experts that will provide science and technology
            advice to implementing agencies on the overall direction and
            progress of all components.
